source.name: If Else
source.instructions:
Drag the appropriate code blocks into the box below. Your program should check to see if a number is even and print "Even". If the number is odd, then print "Odd". Assume the variable `x` represents the number to be tested.

Remember to indent your code!
source.guidance:
Here is the correct answer:

```java
if(x % 2 == 0)
    {System.out.print("Even");}
else
    {System.out.print("Odd");}
```

Here is why the other options are incorrect:

* `if x % 2 = 0` - The equality operator (`==`) is not used.
* `if x / 2 == 0` - The `/` operator is division. To be even, there can be no remainder. The modulo operator (`%`) must be used instead.
* `System.out.print(Even);` - The quotation marks are missing. Without them, Java will try to print the variable `Even`, which has not been declared. 
* `System.out.print(Odd);` - The quotation marks are missing. Without them, Java will try to print the variable `Odd`, which has not been declared.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT construct an if else statement

source.name: If Statements
source.instructions:
Select all of the statements below that are true with regards to if statements. 

**Hint:** There is more than one correct answer.

answers.answer: If statements only ask if a boolean expression is true.
If statements will perform a set of actions if the boolean expression is false.
If statements provide the most precision of all the conditional statements.
If statements are the simplest of all the conditionals.

source.guidance:
The correct answers are:

```
If statements only ask if a boolean expression is true.

If statements are the simplest of all the conditionals.
```

If statements can only ask if a boolean expression is true. An else statement takes into account a false boolean expression.

If statements are the simplest because they ignore when a boolean expression is false, and they do not ask subsequent boolean expressions.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT understand the characteristics of an if statement

source.name: Make a Triangle
source.instructions: Construct a program by drag&dropping and reordering lines from the left to the right. You can change the loop header () by clicking them. The constructed program should draw a triangle like shown below. Hint: You need to indent the lines of code within the loop by dragging the blocks slightly to the right. We'll talk about this next.
source.initial:
REPEAT $$toggle::2::3::4$$ TIMES
forward(100)
left(120)
ENDREPEAT
source.guidance:
The loop header is setting up how many times code is repeated. In the case of a triangle, it makes sense to repeat 3 times - one for each side.

```
REPEAT 3 TIMES
  forward(100)
  left(120)
ENDREPEAT
```
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT... define a loop header

source.name: Make a Square
source.instructions: Construct a program by drag&dropping and reordering lines from the left to the right. You can change the loop header () by clicking them. The constructed program should draw a square like shown below. Be sure to indent the loop body by dragging repeated blocks slightly to the right.
source.initial:
REPEAT $$toggle::2::3::4$$ TIMES
forward(100)
left(90)
ENDREPEAT
source.guidance:
The loop header is setting up how many times code is repeated. In the case of a square, it makes sense to repeat 4 times - one for each side.

The loop body are the lines to be repeated, in this case the blocks instructing the turtle to turn and step forward.

```
REPEAT 4 TIMES
  forward(100)
  left(90)
ENDREPEAT
```
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT... define a loop body

source.name: Loop Vocabulary
source.instructions: Select the appropriate vocabulary words in the paragraph below.
source.text: In code, we use loops to repeat or <<<iterate>>> over sections of code. The <<<loop header>>> indicates how many times the loop will repeat the code. The code section that is repeated is called the <<<loop body>>>.

text: In code, we use loops to repeat or
indicates how many times the loop will repeat the code. The code section that is repeated is called the

source.name: How many repetitions?
source.guidance:
`i` is never incremented, so `i` remains `0` forever. Because `i=0` forever, `i<=5` will ALWAYS be true.

Without the incriminator, we get an infinite loop!

source.name: What is the output?
source.guidance:
Because the print statement is *after* the increment of i, we see values 2-10. Flipping the two lines within the loop body would change the values to 0-8.

Because we do not use fence-posting, we have an extraneous `,` in our output.

source.name: For Loop flow
source.instructions: After completing the loop body, what part of the for loop header is run?
source.guidance: Even though it is the last part of the for loop header, the incrementing is the first piece of the header run after an iteration.

source.name: For Loop Flow
Printing - Reading Question 1
source.instructions:
What is wrong with the code snippet below?
```
System.out.println(Hello world);
```

answers.answer: Add a `;` at the end of the line of code

source.guidance:
After the print command use parentheses and quotation marks around the words to be printed.
```
System.out.print("Hello world");
```

source.name: Printing - Reading Question 2
source.instructions: Which of the following commands adds a newline character?
source.guidance:
`System.out.println("Hello");` inserts a new line character after `Hello` which is hard to see when you only print one line of text. However, if you print two lines like:
```
System.out.println("Hello");
System.out.println("World!");
```
It outputs:
```
Hello
World!
```

source.name: Print Statement
source.instructions: What does the `System.out.print();` or `print` statement do?

answers.answer: Sends your output to the printer
Sends your output to a file
Sends your output to the screen
Sends your output to the compiler

source.guidance: The `print` command sends your output to your computer's default output which is the computer console or terminal.

source.name: Printing with the Newline Character
source.instructions: Fill in the blank with the missing text that will print the text `Hi!` **with** a newline character?
source.text: `System.out.<<<println>>>("Hi!");`
source.guidance: To add the newline character, you use the `println` command instead of the `print` command. The code should look like: `System.out.println("Hi!")`

source.name: Variables - Reading Question 1
source.instructions: Which parts of a variable do *not* change in Java?
source.guidance: For each variable, the data type and name of the variable *never* change. The value can be re-assigned as many times as you want!

source.name: Variables - int vs double
source.instructions: Fill in the following with the appropriate vocabulary to explain the difference between a double and an int.
source.text: A <<<double>>> is a <<<floating point number>>> meaning it has a <<<decimal>>>, where an <<<int>>> is a <<<whole number>>> meaning it does not have a decimal.
source.guidance:
A `double` is a floating point number or a rational number meaning it has a decimal or represents a fraction, where an `int` (short for integer) is a whole number meaning it does not have a decimal.

Both can be positive or negative!

text: meaning it does not have a decimal.

source.name: Variables - Booleans RQ
source.instructions: What is the general rule for boolean values in Java?

answers.answer: Boolean values are case sensitive and must be lowercase.
Boolean values are not case sensitive and can be either uppercase or lowercase.
Boolean values are case sensitive and must be uppercase.
Boolean values are case sensitive and must be all caps.

source.guidance: Boolean values in Java are case sensitive and must start with a lowercase letter: `true` or `false`.

source.name: Declaring Variables
source.instructions: Which of the following code snippets contain correct variable declerations?
source.guidance:
Java does not allow different variables to have the same name - regardless of data type.

Additionally, Java does not allow spaces in variable names - either user `camelCase` or `snake_case` to separate words.

Since Java variables are case sensitive, `var` and `Var` are different variables.

source.name: Variable names
source.instructions: Which of the following is a correct variable name?
source.guidance:
Here are the basic rules for variable names: 
1. Start with a letter, dollar sign or underscore
2. Remainder of variable name is letters, numbers, or underscores
3. Cannot use a Java keyword
4. Variables are case sensitive

source.name: Data Types
source.instructions: What are the four basic data types used in Java?
source.guidance:
The four basic data types that you have learned so far are:

String - collections of letters, numbers, and symbols
boolean - true or false
int - integers (no decimal)
double - numbers with a decimal

source.name: Adding ints and doubles
source.instructions: What happens when you add an int and a double together?
source.guidance:
Since a double can represent the same value as an integer (`2.0` is the same value as `2`), but not necessarily the other way around (`2.4` cannot be an int) the result will be a double. For example:

`7.0 + 3 = 10.0`

source.name: Division
source.instructions: Which of the following statements about division in Java is **FALSE**?

answers.answer: You can use the division operator with `int`s
You will get the same result from the division operator using `int`s and `double`s
You can use the division operator with `double`s
You are not allowed to divide by 0

source.guidance: `int`s and `double`s behave differently with the division operator. Using `double` will result in a decimal where `int` will result in a whole number with the decimal removed. This means that `10/3` is either `3.3333...` or `3` based on data types.

source.name: Modulo
source.instructions: What does modulo (`%`) do?

answers.answer: Determines if a number is even or odd
Determines the percentage of two numbers
Returns the remainder after division is performed

source.guidance: Modulo is the remainder after division is performed. So division is a part of modulo, but modulo is not division. Modulo can be used to determine if a number is even or odd, but modulo can do more than that. Finally, the `%` is used with modulo, but modulo does not deal with percentages.

source.name: Multiplication
source.instructions: Complete the code below so that the program prints the product of `a` and `b`.
source.guidance:
Use `*` for multiplication. You also need to add the variable b, multiplication requires two numbers.

`System.out.println(a * b);`

source.name: Order of Operations
source.instructions: At what point does Java calculate modulo?
source.guidance: Modulo is a type of division, so it is done in order from left to right with the `/` and `*` operators.

source.name: Equating to True
source.instructions:
Which of the following conditions would cause the expression `a <= b` to equate to true? 

**Hint:** there is more than one correct answer.

answers.answer: If `a` is less than and equal to `b`

source.guidance:
There are two conditions that would cause `a <= b` to be true. One is if `a` is less than `b` and the other is `a` is equal to `b`. 

As long as one of those conditions is true, then `a <= b` will be true.

source.name: Many ways to tie a not
source.instructions: Evaluate the two expressions below.
source.text:
`5 != 4` returns <<<true>>>
`! 5 == 4` returns <<<true>>>
source.guidance: Both values evaluate to `true`. In the second case, 5==4 first evaluates to `false` and then `! false` evaluates to `true`.

source.name: Short Circuiting
source.instructions: Use the dropdown menus to complete the text below.
source.text:
## Or Operator
When using the `||` operator, Java checks to see if the first boolean expression is <<<true>>>. If it is <<<true>>>, Java returns <<<true>>> and ignores the second boolean expression.

## And Operator
When using the `&&` operator, Java checks to see if the first boolean expression is <<<false>>>. If it is <<<false>>>, Java returns <<<false>>> and ignores the second boolean expression.
source.guidance:
If the first boolean expression for the `||` operator is true, then the entire thing is true. The second boolean expression is ignored.

If the first boolean expression for the `&&` operator is false, then the entire thing is false. The second boolean expression is ignored.

text:
## Or Operator
When using the `||` operator, Java checks to see if the first boolean expression is

and ignores the second boolean expression.

## And Operator
When using the `&&` operator, Java checks to see if the first boolean expression is
and ignores the second boolean expression.

source.name: Evaluating Expressions
source.instructions:
Using your knowledge of boolean operators, choose the best answer about evaluating the below:

`( 5 != 4 ) && ( 3 > 0 ) && ( ! 2 == 3 ) || #unknown condition#`

answers.answer: The answer if `false` - Java short circuits because you have a `false` condition with an `&&` operator
The answer if `true` - Java short circuits because you have a `true` condition with an `||` operator
There is not enough information - we would need to know the "unknown condition"

source.guidance: Because the first three conditions evaluate as true, when combined with `&&` evaluates as true. When you reach the `||` operator you then have `true || #unknown condition#`. Java short circuits and evaluates the entire line as `true` without ever evaluating the #unknown condition#.

source.name: Boolean Operators
source.instructions:
Determine if the code below returns true or false.

`(7 >= 7) && (true || 99 < 1) || ! (3 > 5 && 7 < 10) && 2 != 4`
source.guidance:
First, start by evaluating the expressions in the parentheses.

`( 7 >= 7)` returns true.
`(true || 99 < 1)` returns true
`! (3 > 5 && 7 < 10)` returns true
`2 != 4` returns true
So the boolean expression is now `true && true || true && true`, which returns true.

source.guidance: Only the `+` operator can be used with Strings. It serves as the concatenation operator - merging two strings together.

source.name: Order of Operations
source.instructions:
Drag the blocks into the correct order of operations.

**Hint:** You will not need all the blocks - and make sure to explicitly list when modulo is done!
source.initial:
Parentheses
Exponents
Multiplication and Division and Modulo
Addition and Subtraction
Parentheses and Exponents #distractor
Multiplication and Division #distractor
Modulo #distractor
source.guidance: Order of operations starts with any expression in parentheses. Next, any exponents are calculated. Then multiplication and division (including modulo) are done moving from left to right. Finally, addition and subtraction are done moving from left to right.

source.name: Evaluating Mixed Operator Expressions
source.instructions:
What is the results of the following expression?

```
! (5 != 3) && (5 % 3 >= 2)
```
source.guidance:
Starting with parentheses, `5 != 3` is `true`. So `! true` would be `false`. 

Using the short circuit principal, we can stop evaluating the problem because when we use the `&&` operator, both boolean expressions must be `true` for it to return `true`. Since we have `false` for the first expression, it cannot be `true`.

source.name: Compilation Error
source.instructions: When you have the compilation error fixed, submit by clicking the button below.
source.guidance:
The compilation bug is located on the following line:
```
boolean b = 9;
```

The bug is that `b` is declared as a `boolean` but is being assigned `9` which is an `int`. To correct this, you would replace `boolean` with `int` which results in:
```
int b = 9;
```

source.name: If Statement
source.instructions: What does an if statement *not* do?

answers.answer: Allows specific code to run only when the boolean expression is true.
If the boolean expression is false, the program never reaches the if statement.
Allows your program to make decisions about what to do.
Checks to see if a certain condition is true.

source.guidance: The program will only know the boolean expression is false after reaching the if statement. The first line with the `if` keyword is always checked, it is the code in the `{}` which will not be run if the boolean expression is false.

source.name: Even numbers
source.instructions: Complete the if statements below so that it will determine if the variable `num` is even or odd.

source.name: If Else Syntax
source.instructions:
Which of the following are true about using an if-else? 

*Hint:* There is more than one right answer.

answers.answer: Indentation effects how the code runs
You should use curly braces `{}` after both the `if` condition and the `else` keyword to group code that is conditionally executed
The `else` condition does not have another boolean expression
There should be empty parentheses `()` after the `else` keyword

source.guidance:
Java uses curly braces to group code commands. While indention is helpful, it does not effect how the program runs. Instead, you need to use curly braces to tell Java what code runs in both the true condition (after the `if`) and the false condition (after the `else`).

Additionally, because `else` refers to the `if`, it does not need its own boolean expression. Nor does it need parentheses.

answers.answer: A closing curly brace is missing before the `else` keyword
Parentheses are missing after the `else` keyword
An open curly brace is missing after the `else` keyword
Parentheses are missing around the boolean expression after the `if` keyword

source.name: Compound Conditionals
source.instructions:
Why would you want to use a compound conditional? 

**Hint:** There is more than one right answer

answers.answer: If two or more thing have to be true.
When you want your code to be faster.
You will get an error message if you don't use a compound conditional.
When you want your code to be more concise and easy to read.

source.guidance: Compound conditionals allow you to test two or more things to be true, and they make your code more concise and easy to read.

source.name: Nested If Else
source.instructions:
Construct code that will print out messages based on the weather:
 * "Bring an umbrella!" if it is rainy but *not* windy
 * "Wear a rain jacket." if it is rainy and windy
 * "You might need a coat." if it is cold but *not* rainy
 * "Enjoy your day!" if it is *not* cold and *not* rainy

Assume the following boolean variables have already been declared and initialized: `rainy`, `windy`, `cold`

source.name: Switch Case Syntax
source.instructions: Which of the following code snippets has the **correct** switch case syntax?
source.guidance:
`switch (num) { `
The `switch` keyword is followed by the variable in parentheses. 
The case statements are surrounded by curly braces.

`case "one" : number = 1; break;`
Each case keyword is followed by a value and `:`
After the code that should run if the variable == value, a `break;` ends the switch case.

`default: number = -1;`
It is best practice to have the final case be `default`. Since it is the final case, it does not need a `break;` statement.

source.name: Switch Case or If Else?
source.instructions: Which of the following would be most appropriate for a `switch` statement?

answers.answer: Providing different types information about a caller's bank account (or re-directing the call) based on the number they pressed on their keypad
Generating the overall and category (male under 20, male over 50, female under 20, female over 50, etc) winners of a 5k race
Using a car's mileage and service history to list what work needs to be done

source.guidance:
Generating race winners requires comparing unknown times and for categories you will need a compound conditional -- so you need `if else`.

Similarly, a car's milage is going to fall into a range. Additionally, you will need to check against variables to see if the service has been done -- so you need `if else`.

A `switch` would work well in the phone example since the user can only press 10 discrete buttons with constant values.

source.name: Summation Using a For Loop
source.instructions:
Construct a program using the code blocks below that incorporates a `for` loop to find the sum of all numbers between 1 and 100, and then prints that cumulative sum. The program should **include both 1 and 100** in the sum.

**Hint:** You will not need to use all of the blocks and be sure to **indent** any command(s) that you want the system to repeat by dragging it slightly to the right. You only have **ONE ATTEMPT** at this problem!

source.name: For Loop Headers
source.instructions:
Which of the following `for` loop headers will loop **exactly** 100 times? Ignore the value of the iterating variable and focus on the **number of times** the loop body will be executed.

**Note:** There may be more than one correct answer.
source.guidance:
Only choices #1 and #4 are correct because they are both executed **exactly** 100 times. `for (int i = 0; i < 100; i++)` goes from 0 to 99 and `for (int i = 1; i <= 100; i++)` goes from 1 to 100. Both of those ranges include 100 iterations.

`for (int i = 0; i <= 100; i++)` goes from 0 to 100 which is a total of 101 iterations.

`for (int i = 1; i < 100; i++)` goes from 1 to 99 which is only 99 iterations.

source.name: Infinite While Loop
source.instructions: Which of the following code snippets will result in an **infinite** `while` loop?
source.guidance:
Only choice #3 will result in an infinite `while` loop because `lives` will never reach `0` or less to terminate the loop. 

The `while` loops in choices #1 and #4 are not executed because the boolean expression in the loop header never evaluates to true. 

The `while` loop in choice #2 executes but is ended once `lives` reaches `0` due to `lives` being decremented after each iteration.

source.name: Infinite Loop Solution

answers.answer: Insert a `break;` statement on the line after `System.out.println("You successfully entered a lowercase vowel.");`.
Insert a `break;` statement on the line after `System.out.println("You did not enter a lowercase vowel.");`.

source.guidance:
By definition, an **infinite loop** occurs when a program has no test conditions to cause a loop to stop. The program above will indefinitely ask the user for input and store that input regardless of what the user enters.

Choices #1 and #2 are correct because they will offer a condition for the loop to stop depending on what the user enters.

Choice #3 will result in errors because the `for` loop syntax is incorrect. The program can still run, but the infinite loop is not resolved.

Choice #4 will result in an error because the String `s` needs to be initialized.

source.name: Recognizing For Loop Pattern
source.guidance: All of the choices above are correct **except** choice #2. It's important to recognize that the `tina.forward(100);` and `tina.right(90);` commands occur exactly **four** times. Thus, a loop that iterates those commands four times is needed. While all of the choices have a loop header that runs four times, choice #2 has a header that only runs **three** times and is therefore incorrect.

source.name: For Loop Iterator Variable
source.instructions:
Here is the output to a sample program:

```java
2
4
6
8
10
```
Fill in the blanks below so that the loop outputs what's shown above.
source.guidance:
First, it is important to determine the pattern of the output. `2` is printed first and `10` is printed last. In addition, the numbers from `2` through `10` are printed in increments of `2`s. Noticing this pattern enables us to fill out the loop header like so: 
`for (int n=2; n<=10; n+=2)`

Finally, we need to print the output. Remember that the loop iterator variable `n` is an integer itself so it can be printed like so:
`System.out.println(n);`

source.name: While vs. For Loops
source.instructions: Fill in the blanks below with either `while` or `for`.
source.text:
A <<<while>>> loop usually contains a boolean expression(s) in its header and nothing else.
A <<<for>>> loop contains a header that specifies where an iterator variable starts, where it ends, and how it is changed per iteration.
A <<<for>>> loop is better if a command needs to be executed a certain number of times.
A counting variable needs to be declared and initialized before a <<<while>>> loop can be executed properly.
source.guidance: One big difference between a `while` loop and a `for` loop is that a `while` loop only contains a boolean expression(s) within its header. That means a counting variable must be declared and initialized before a `while` loop can be used properly. On the other hand, the header of a `for` loop contains an iterator variable which helps to determine how many times the `for` loop will run.

loop usually contains a boolean expression(s) in its header and nothing else.
A

loop contains a header that specifies where an iterator variable starts, where it ends, and how it is changed per iteration.
A

loop is better if a command needs to be executed a certain number of times.
A counting variable needs to be declared and initialized before a

source.name: For Loop to While Loop
Break Statement Purpose
source.instructions: What purpose does the `break` statement serve?

answers.answer: The `break` statement is used to pause a program so that it can run at a later time.
The `break` statement is required in every `while` loop to separate sections of code.
The `break` statement is used to end a program.
The `break` statement is used to stop and exit a loop.

source.guidance: The `break` statement is used to stop and exit a loop **not** a program. `break` statements are often used to prevent situations where an infinite loop might be involved; however, `break` statements are not always required.

source.name: While Loop Syntax
source.instructions: Fill in the blanks below so that the `while` loop prints `Java` **10** times.
source.guidance: The counting variable that is being used in the code is called `count`. If `count` is initialized to `0`, then **ten iterations** will cause it to stop at `9`. Thus, `count < 10` is the correct loop header. `count = count + 1` does the same  thing as `count++` and will increment the counting variable by `1` after during each iterations.

source.name: Break Statement Syntax
source.instructions: Fill in the blanks such that the loop will **stop and exit** after it has run **100** times.
source.guidance: `total` is the counting variable that is used in the code above. To increment `total` so that it iterates **100 times**, `total = total + 1` is needed. Since `total` starts at `0` and we want it to iterate 100 times before stopping, we will insert a `break` statement to stop the loop once `total > 99` becomes true. The range from `0` through `99` is a total of exactly 100 iterations.

source.name: Nested Loops
source.instructions: Which definition best describes a nested loop?

answers.answer: A nested loop is when you have two loops that run one after the other.
A nested loop is when you have a `while` loop and a `for` loop in the same program.
A nested loop is when a loop exists inside another loop.
A nested loop is when you have more than one loop in your program.

source.guidance: By definition, a **nested loop** is when one loop exists inside another loop. There are are restrictions on the type of loop that can be nested nor the number of nested loops that can be used (though it is rare to implement more than two nested loops). Thus, a `for` loop can be nested in another `for` loop and a `while` loop can be nested inside another `while` loop. In addition, a `for` loop can be nested inside a `while` loop and vice versa.

source.name: Array Syntax
source.instructions: Which of the following correctly contains the syntax for creating an **integer** array called `numbers` that stores elements from **1 through 5**?
source.guidance: In order to store integers into an array, `int[]` must be used. Also, we know we want elements in the array to be initialized to numbers 1 through 5 which means we cannot use `new`. Thus, the correct answer is `int[] numbers = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT Create an array using both the initializer list and new methods

source.name: Array Indices
source.instructions:
Given the following code:
```java
double[] tenths = {1.2, 2.3, 3.4, 4.5};
```

Determine what will be printed for each of the following print statements.
source.text:
1. `System.out.println(tenths[0])` will print <<<1.2>>>.
2. `System.out.println(tenths[2])` will print <<<3.4>>>.
3. `System.out.println(tenths[4])` will print <<<ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException>>>.
source.guidance: Remember that array indices always start at `0`. Thus, `tenths[0]` refers to the first element, `tenths[2]` refers to the third element, and `tenths[4]` refers to the fifth element. The first element is `1.2`, the third element is `3.4`, and the fifth element does not exist. Therefore, an `ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException` error message will be returned.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT Access and modify array elements

First test: 84
Second test: 76
Third test: 97

source.name: Modifying Array Elements
source.instructions:
After outputting your code, you noticed that `Friday` is printed twice. Your code is shown below:
```java
String[] weekdays = {"Monday", "Tuesday", "Wednesday", 
                     "Friday", "Friday"};
```

Which of the following code snippets correctly modifies the array so that `Thursday` is printed **after** `Wednesday` but **before** the second `Friday`?
source.guidance: In order to modify an array element, you must specify the index at which that element is located within brackets `[]`. Also, remember that array indices start at `0` for the first element, then `1` for the second element, etc. Since we want to replace the first `Friday` with `Thursday`, which is the fourth element in the array, we need to access index number `3`. Thus, the correct answer is choice **#2**: `weekdays[3] = "Thursday";`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT Access and modify array elements

source.name: Iterating Array Elements
source.instructions:
Construct a program using the code blocks below that iterates through the array and prints every element inside.

**Hint:** You will not need to use all of the blocks and be sure to **indent** any command(s) that you want the program to repeat by dragging it slightly to the right. You only have **ONE ATTEMPT** at this problem!
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT Iterate through arrays using a for loop

source.name: Enhanced For-Loop
source.instructions: Which of the following situations can an enhanced `for` loop be used for?

answers.answer: To refer to an array index or position within the array.
To modify an element inside the array.
To print all of the elements within an array.
To print only specific elements of the array.

source.guidance: The biggest advantage of an enhanced `for` loop is that it cuts down on the amount of code needed to **print all of the elements** inside an array. Unfortunately, it cannot access array indices, modify array elements, nor print specific elements within an array.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT Iterate through arrays using an enhanced for loop

source.name: Conditional Array Output
source.guidance:
**Guide:**
* The elements `18`, `21`, `15`, `2`, and `68` are added to the array called `ages`.
* An enhanced `for` loop is used which causes `i` to take on the value of each element.
* If `i` is greater than or equal to `18`, then the system prints `Eligible`.
* Otherwise, the system will print `Ineligible`.
* `18`, `21`, and `68` will result in `Eligible` since they are greater than or equal to `18`.
* `15` and `2` are less than `18` so they will result in `Ineligible`.

**Solution:**
```java
Eligible
Eligible
Ineligible
Ineligible
Eligible
```
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT Determine array output

source.name: ArrayList Syntax
source.instructions: Which of the following ArrayList syntax is **incorrect**?
source.guidance: There are *unique* labels for data types in ArrayLists. Instead of `int`, `double`, and `boolean`, ArrayLists use `Integer`, `Double`, and `Boolean`. Only `String`s is similarly used between ArrayLists and arrays. Thus, it should be `ArrayList<Integer> list = new ArrayList<Integer>();` rather than `ArrayList<int> list = new ArrayList<int>();`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT Create an empty ArrayList

source.name: Adding and Removing ArrayList Elements
source.guidance:
By following the syntax for adding and removing ArrayList elements, you should end up with the output `[I, really, hate, bean sprouts]`.

**Code Flow:**
`words.add("I");` ---> `[I]`
`words.add("love");` ---> `[I, love]`
`words.remove(1);` ---> `[I]`
`words.add("hate");` ---> `[I, hate]`
`words.add(1, "really");` ---> `[I, really, hate]`
`words.add(3, "bean sprouts");` ---> `[I, really, hate, bean sprouts]`
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT Add and remove ArrayList elements

source.name: ArrayList or Array?
source.instructions: Fill out the following statements with either `ArrayList` or `Array` depending on whether each statement is true to one or the other.
source.text:
1. Can be initialized by adding elements into curly braces `{}`: <<<Array>>>
2. Can add or remove elements after being created: <<<ArrayList>>>
3. Can change the order of elements without modifying existing elements: <<<ArrayList>>>
4. Can use `length` to determine the number of elements: <<<Array>>>
source.guidance:
Although it is possible to initialize elements at the start, arrays are **static** so adding or removing elements *after* initialization is not possible. On the other hand, ArrayLists are **dynamic** so it is possible to add, remove, and reorder elements. Arrays use `length` while ArrayLists use `size()` to determine the number of existing elements.

**Solution:**
1. Array
2. ArrayList
3. ArrayList
4. Array
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT Determine key differences between ArrayLists and arrays

text: 1. Can be initialized by adding elements into curly braces `{}`:
2. Can add or remove elements after being created:
3. Can change the order of elements without modifying existing elements:
4. Can use `length` to determine the number of elements:

source.name: ArrayLists, Loops, and Conditionals
source.instructions:
On a student's first four tests, they received scores in the following order: `68`, `92`, `100`, and `88`.

Fill in the blanks below with code so that the program will print `You got a perfect score!` if the student scored as least one `100` and will print `Keep up the hard work!` if they did not.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT Determine ArrayList output

source.name: Modifying a Shopping List
source.instructions:
Your shopping list is stored in an ArrayList and when printed gives you the following output:
```java
Apple
Banana
Banana
Dumpling
```
You notice that you accidentally added `Banana` twice and you had meant to add `Carrot` after the *first* `Banana`. Assuming that your ArrayList is called `list`, which of the following commands will modify `list` so that printing it will produce:
```java
Apple
Banana
Carrot
Dumpling
```
source.guidance: Only choice **#4** will modify the `list` so that `Carrot` will replace `Banana` at index 2. Choice **#1** will only add `Carrot` to the end of the `list`. Choice **#2** will only remove the second `Banana` stored at index 2. And finally, choice **#3** will just access index 1 without modifying any elements.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT Modify ArrayList elements

source.name: Decoding the Message

answers.answer: `a bad today is good a today`

source.guidance:
To decode the message, follow each commands below:
* message.add("a"); ---> [a]
* message.add("bad"); ---> [a, bad]
* message.add(0, "today"); ---> [today, a, bad]
* message.set(1, "is"); ---> [today, is, bad]
* message.remove(2); ---> [today, is]
* message.add("good"); ---> [today, is, good]
* message.add(2, "a"); ---> [today, is, a, good]
* message.add("day"); ---> [today, is, a, good, day]
* System.out.print(s); ---> `todayisagoodday`

**Note** that the enhanced for loop will iterate through the elements and print them **without** any newlines nor spaces.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT Determine ArrayList output

source.name: 2D Array Creation
source.instructions: If you want to create a 2D array with `2` rows and `4` columns that stores **integer** elements, which of the following syntax should you use?
source.guidance:
`Integer` is used for ArrayLists, not arrays. Remember, a 2D array is just an array inside another array. Therefore, the correct type is `int`. When creating a 2D array, the numbers that go into the brackets represent how many rows and columns will be created, not the row and column indices.

**Solution:**
`int[][] elements = new int[2][4];`
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT Create a 2D array using the initializer list method

source.name: 2D Array Modification
source.instructions:
Given the following 2D array:
```java
double[][] sqroots = { {1.00, 1.41, 1.73},
                       {2.00, 2.2, 2.45} };
```

Which of the following code snippets will enable you to change `2.2` within the 2D array to `2.24`?
source.guidance:
Remember that array indices start at `0`, **not** at `1`. Thus, `2.2` is located at row index 1 and column index 1. To access an element inside a 2D array, the row and column indices must go into brackets `[][]`.

**Solution:**
`sqroots[1][1] = 2.24;`
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT Access and modify 2D array elements

source.guidance:
The program creates a 2D array and populates each index with Strings. Then some elements are printed with a newline while others are printed with a space. The solution guide below shows the sequence in which the elements are populated. Note that the `x`'s represent placeholders.

**Solution Guide:**
* Empty 2D array:
```java
x x
x x
x x
```
* `names[0][1] = "First name";`
```java
x First name
x x
x x
```
* `names[0][0] = "Last name";`
```java
Last name First name
x x
x x
```
* `names[2][0] = "Man";`
```java
Last name First name
x x
Man x
```
* `names[1][1] = "Peter";`
```java
Last name First name
x Peter
Man x
```
* `names[1][0] = "Parker";`
```java
Last name First name
Parker Peter
Man x
```
* `names[2][1] = "Spider";`
```java
Last name First name
Parker Peter
Man Spider
```
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT Determine 2D array output

source.instructions:

1. Iterates through the array and modifies it so that elements at even indices are changed to `true` and elements at odd indices remain `false`.

true false true false true

source.name: ArrayList Size
source.instructions: Select **all** of the following methods that will affect an ArrayList's size. In other words, the number of elements is changed by the method(s).
source.guidance: Both the `add()` and `remove()` methods will affect the size of the ArrayList. The size of the ArrayList will increase by one after `add()` is used and will decrease by 1 after `removed()` is used. `get()` and `set()` will access and modify an element respectively, but they do not change the size of the ArrayList.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT Understand ArrayList methods

source.name: Wrong Number
source.instructions:
Given the 2D array output:
```java
1 2 3
4 5 0
7 8 9
```

If this 2D array was initialized as `int[][] keypad = new int[3][3];`, which of the following statements will modify the 2D array so that `6` is printed as an element instead of `0`?
source.guidance: The 2D array is of type `int`, therefore the element has to be an integer `6` rather than a String `"6"`. 2D array indices start at 0, not 1; therefore, `0` is located at row index 1 and column index 2. To change `0` to `6`, the correct command is `keypad[1][2] = 6;`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT Determine correct 2D array syntax

source.name: writing to a file reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

What method is used to write to a file?
source.guidance: The `write` method is used to write text to a file in Java.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify the method used to write strings to a text file

source.name: more writing to files reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

You want to write the following text to a file:

```
One upon a time
In a land far, far away
Lived a king and queen
```

Assume that `writer` is a `FileWriter` object. Select all of the valid ways you can do this. **Hint**, there is more than one right answer.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT write properly formatted text to a file

source.name: file basics reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Why is it preferable to use `BufferedWriter` as opposed to just `FileWriter`?

answers.answer: `BufferedWriter` writes to memory, which is faster than writing directly to disk.
`FileWriter` is no longer supported by Java.
`BufferedWriter` writes directly to disk, which is faster than writing to memory.
There is no class called `FileWriter` in Java.

source.guidance: Remember, reading and writing to memory is much faster than reading or writing to disk. So using `BufferedWriter` will be faster than `FileWriter` because `BufferedWriter` writes to memory while `FileWriter` writes to disk.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain why buffers are useful

source.name: appending to a file reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Fill in the blanks below with words from the dropdown menu.
source.text:
<<<Writing>>> to a file will erase its contents before adding the string.
<<<Appending>>> to a file will keep its contents and add the string at the end.
source.guidance:
**Writing** to a file will overwrite it. That means all existing content will be replaced with the new content.
**Appending** to a file keeps the existing content and adds the new content at the end of the file.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT differentiate between writing and appending to a file

text: to a file will erase its contents before adding the string.
to a file will keep its contents and add the string at the end.

source.name: writing a file formative assessment 1
source.instructions:
## Formative Assessment

Rearrange the code blocks below to create a program that writes the following information to the file `tongueTwister.txt`.

```
Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers
A peck of pickled peppers Peter Piper picked
If Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers
Wheres the peck of pickled peppers Peter Piper picked?
```
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT demonstrate writing to a file

source.name: writing to a file formative assessment 2
source.instructions:
## Formative Assessment

Assume that you have the text file `quotes.txt`. Rearrange the code blocks below to create a program that will add the following text to the file. Your program should not alter any information already in the text file. This quote should be on its own line in the file. 

```text
"The time is always right to do what is right."
```

**Note**, not all of the code blocks will be used.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT append a string to a file

source.name: reading question skip method
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Assume that `reader` is a `BufferedReader` object and that the first line of a text file has 22 characters.
source.guidance: The correct answers are those where the `skip` method has an argument that is positive and less than 22 (the number of characters in the line). When the argument is greater than 22, Java will return text from the second line of the file. Java will return an error if the argument is negative.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT use the skip method to ignore a set of characters when reading a file

source.name: reading question reading a file
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Select the true statement about reading files in Java.

answers.answer: The `readLine` method reads from the file until it encounters a newline character.
The `readLine` method reads the entire file at once.
The `read` method reads from the file until it encounters a newline character.
The `read` method reads the entire file at once.

source.guidance: The `readLine` method reads from the file until it comes across a newline character. The `read` method reads only one character at a time.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define what the readLine method does

source.name: reading question file iteration
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Why do the examples on this page use a while loop instead of a for loop?

answers.answer: We want to iteration until a condition is met (the end of the file) as opposed to iterating a specific number of times.
Java throws an error when reading a file with a for loop.
For loops are slower than while loops.

source.guidance:
The correct answer is: 

```
You want to iteration until a condition is met (the end of the file) as opposed to iterating a specific number of times.
```

We do not know how many lines of text there are in a file. A for loop is not a good choice because it runs a specified number of times. Instead, use a while loop to test for the end of the file. This way your loop runs the correct amount of iterations.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain why a while loop is preferable to a for loop when iterating over a file

source.name: reading question tokens
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT create tokens from a string read from a file

source.name: read and write reading question
source.text:
In **Code Example 1**, Java reads from the file stored in the variable <<<myFile1.txt>>> and writes to file stored in variable <<<myFile2.txt>>>.

In **Code Example 2**, Java reads from the file stored in the variable <<<myFile4.txt>>> and writes to file stored in variable <<<myFile3.txt>>>.
source.guidance:
In the first example, Java is reading from `myFile1.txt` and writing to `myFile2.txt`.
In the second example, Java is reading from `myFile4.txt` and writing to `myFile3.txt`.

tags.name: Category
tags.value: Read a file, write to a file

source.learningObjectives: SWBAT determine which file is being read and which file is being written to

and writes to file stored in variable

.

In **Code Example 2**, Java reads from the file stored in the variable
and writes to file stored in variable

source.name: csv files reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Assume the variable `path` contains the file path to a CSV file. What is the proper way to declare an object work with CSV files using Opencsv?
source.guidance:
The correct answer is:

```java
CSVReader reader = new CSVReader(new FileReader(path));
```

* The `BufferedReader` class is not used when working with CSV files
* The `CSVReader` class is wrapped around a `Filewriter` object
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT declare a CSVReader object

source.name: printing an csv file reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question
How is the data for each row in a CSV file stored once it is read?
source.guidance: Once a CSV has been read, each row is stored as an array of strings. So manipulating CSV information is based on working with arrays (indexing, slicing, methods, functions, etc.) and working with strings (printing, methods, etc.).
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify how CSV data is stored once it has been read

source.name: what does a delimiter do
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

What is the purpose of a delimiter?

answers.answer: A delimiter is a character that separates units of data.
A delimiter is a character that marks the end of a line.
A delimiter is a character that begins a line of data.
A delimiter is a character that marks the end of a file.

source.guidance:
A delimiter is a character that separates units of data. In a CSV file, the default delimiter is a comma. Here is an example of a file with a comma delimiter:

Name,Breed
Bear,German Shepherd
Roxy,Black Lab
Bella,Yorkie
Lucky,Terrier
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define a delimiter

source.name: reading/writing to CSV files
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Fill in the blanks below.
source.text:
The <<<CSVReader>>> object is used to read a CSV file.
The <<<CSVWriter>>> object is used to write to a CSV file.
source.guidance: The `CSVReader` object is used to read CSV files, while the `CSVWriter` object is used to write to a CSV file. The `BufferedReader` and `BufferedWriter` objects are used to read and write to text files.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify the objects used to read and write to CSV files

text:
object is used to read a CSV file.
The
object is used to write to a CSV file.

source.name: csv formative assessment 1
source.instructions:
## Formative Assessment

Assume that the variable `path` contains a file path to a CSV file. Rearrange the code blocks below to read the file and print the contents line by line. **Note**, not all of the code blocks will be used.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT iterate over a CSV and print each row

source.name: delimiter formative assessment
source.instructions:
## Formative Assessment

You are reading from a CSV file that uses `|` as the delimiter. How would separate the string `row` into an array of tokens with the delimiter?
source.guidance:
The correct answer is:

```java
row.split("|")
```

* The method is `split`, which is why `separate` is incorrect
* The `split` method splits a string based on a string not a character, which is why `'|'` is incorrect
* The string to be split is `row`, which is why `line` is incorrect
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT to parse a CSV file with a delimiter that is not a comma

source.name: files lab question 1
source.instructions:
## Lab Question

Why does the code above say `System.out.println(text.get(0))` instead of `System.out.println(text)`?

answers.answer: The variable `text` is an ArrayList of strings. If you print `text`, it will print the entirety of the list  including square brackets. Printing `text.get(0)` will print just the text, no square brackets.
Both `System.out.println(text.get(0))` and `System.out.println(text)` print the same thing.
Text files require `System.out.println(text.get(0))` while CSV files require `System.out.println(text)`.

source.guidance: The variable `text` is an ArrayList of strings. If you print `text`, it will print the entirety of the list  including square brackets. Printing `text.get(0)` will print just the first element in the ArrayList, no square brackets. If you want the text, print the string inside the list, not the list itself.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT demonstrate how to read the contents of a file into a variable and then manipulate the text in the variable

source.name: lab 2 lab question
source.instructions:
## Lab Question

Select the correct line of code that would allow you to append to a text file rather than overwriting it.

answers.answer: BufferedWriter writer = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter(path, true));
BufferedWriter writer = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter(path, append));
BufferedWriter writer = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter(true, path));

source.guidance:
The correct answer is:

```java
BufferedWriter writer = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter(path, true));
```

The boolean value `true` is used after the file path in the `FileWriter` object.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT demonstrate how to append to a text file

source.name: lab 3 question
source.instructions:
## Lab Question

Assume the variable `line` is a string read from a text file. Drag the blocks below so that you create tokens for each word using a `StringTokenizer` object. **Important**, not all of the blocks will be used.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT create tokens from a string read from a file

source.name: lab 4 question
source.instructions:
## Lab Question

What would happen if you removed the following line of code from the Caesar cipher?

```java
destination.newLine();
```

answers.answer: The resulting text would be one long sentence as there would be no newline characters. The `write` method does not add a newline character.
Nothing, the output would be the same.
Removing that line of code would remove the blank line between paragraphs.

source.guidance: When you read line from a text file, Java will read up until the newline character. The newly read line does not include the newline character. So when you write the same line to a new file, you need to add a newline character to preserve the original format.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain why it is important to manually new lines when writing to a file.
